definitions: feeling or showing pleasure, contentment, or joy about something
causing or characterized by feelings of pleasure or satisfaction
fortunate and convenient; occurring by pleasing chance or circumstance
examples: The happy children played in the park all afternoon
She felt happy when she received the good news
We spent a happy evening with old friends
The movie had a happy ending that pleased everyone
It was a happy coincidence that we met there
By happy accident, they discovered the perfect solution

definitions: transparent, allowing light to pass through; free from obstruction
easy to perceive, understand, or interpret without confusion or ambiguity
free from doubt, confusion, or uncertainty; obvious or evident
examples: The clear water allowed us to see the fish
We need to clear the path of fallen branches
Her instructions were clear and easy to follow
The professor gave a clear explanation of the concept
It's clear that we need to change our approach
The evidence made his innocence clear to everyone

definitions: no longer alive; having lost all vital functions permanently
lacking activity, movement, energy, or power; completely inactive or inoperative
complete, absolute, or exact in degree, position, or timing
examples: The dead leaves covered the forest floor
They found a dead bird in the garden
The phone line went dead during the storm
The town was dead quiet at midnight
She hit the target dead center
He was dead wrong about the answer

definitions: of, affecting, or belonging to a particular person rather than anyone else
concerning one's private life, relationships, and emotions rather than public matters
directed toward or intended for a particular person in an individual way
examples: She keeps her personal belongings in a locked drawer
This is my personal opinion on the matter
He doesn't discuss personal matters at work
They asked personal questions about her family life
The manager gave personal attention to each complaint
She received a personal invitation from the president

definitions: relating to or characteristic of soldiers, arms, or war; connected with armed forces
having the disciplined characteristics or bearing associated with soldiers or warfare
examples: Military operations began at dawn
He served in the military for twenty years
She walks with military precision
The school maintains military discipline

definitions: allowing access, passage, or view; not closed, fastened, or restricted
available for use, business, or participation; accessible to all
frank and communicative; willing to talk or share information honestly
examples: The open door let in fresh air
We drove through open countryside
The store is open until nine tonight
The position is still open for applications
She's very open about her feelings
We need an open discussion about this issue

definitions: existing, occurring, or carried on between two or more nations or their citizens
known, recognized, or operating in many countries around the world
examples: International trade agreements benefit all participating countries
The airport handles both domestic and international flights
She became an international celebrity after the Olympics
The company has an international reputation for quality

definitions: completely confident or sure about something; having no doubt
particular but not explicitly named or specified; some but not all
sure to happen or come; established beyond doubt as inevitable
examples: I'm certain that we locked the door
She was certain of her decision
Certain students will need extra help
There are certain rules we must follow
Death and taxes are certain in life
Victory seemed certain after their strong start

definitions: having happened, begun, or been done not long ago; belonging to past time comparatively near present
belonging to or occurring in times comparatively close to present; modern
examples: Recent events have changed our plans
She graduated from college in recent years
Recent technology has transformed communication
The museum features both ancient and recent art

definitions: able to be used, obtained, or accessed; at someone's disposal
free and able to be seen or contacted; not otherwise occupied
examples: Fresh fruit is available at the market
Limited tickets are still available for tonight's show
The doctor is available on Tuesday afternoons
I'll be available to meet after lunch

definitions: completely prepared or in fit condition for immediate action or use
willing or eager to do something; mentally disposed or inclined
likely or about to do something specified; on the verge of
examples: Dinner is ready to be served
The athletes were ready for the competition
She's ready to help whenever needed
Are you ready to start the meeting?
The volcano looks ready to erupt
The fruit is ready to fall from the tree

definitions: only one; not one of several or part of a pair
not married or not in a romantic relationship with someone
considered or regarded separately from each other; individual or distinct
examples: A single mistake ruined the entire project
She didn't miss a single day of work
He's been single for two years
Single people often pay higher taxes
Every single student passed the exam
We examined each single piece of evidence

definitions: belonging to the present time; happening or being done now
relating to the flow of water, air, or electricity in particular direction
modern and following the latest developments, fashions, or trends
examples: The current situation requires immediate attention
What's your current address?
The river's current is strong after the rain
Electrical current flows through the wire
She keeps up with current fashion trends
The software uses current technology standards

definitions: having a high probability of occurring or being true; probable
apparently suitable, appropriate or promising for a particular purpose
examples: Rain is likely this afternoon
It's likely that prices will increase next year
She's a likely candidate for the promotion
This seems like a likely spot for camping

definitions: affecting or concerning all or most people, places, or things; widespread
not specialized or limited; considering or including only main features
chief or principal in rank; having overall responsibility or command
examples: The general opinion favors the new policy
There was general agreement about the proposal
She gave a general overview of the topic
We discussed the plan in general terms
The general manager oversees all departments
She was promoted to general counsel

definitions: measuring a small distance from end to end; not long
lasting or taking a small amount of time; brief in duration
insufficient, deficient, or lacking in amount, extent, or degree
examples: She has short black hair
The rope is too short to reach
We took a short break for lunch
It's only a short walk to the store
We're short of funds this month
The recipe calls for butter but we're short

definitions: of a color at the end of spectrum next to orange; color of blood
relating to or supporting socialism, communism, or radical leftist politics
flushed in the face from anger, embarrassment, or strong emotion
examples: She wore a bright red dress
The red roses were beautiful
The red flag symbolized the revolution
He was accused of having red sympathies
His face turned red with embarrassment
She was red with anger after the argument

definitions: at or within a short distance in space or time; near
having a strong personal relationship; intimate, familiar, or affectionate
very similar to or almost the same as something; nearly accurate
examples: The pharmacy is close to the hospital
We live close to the beach
They've been close friends since childhood
She's very close to her grandmother
Your guess was close to the actual number
The translation is close to the original meaning

definitions: relating to the science or practice of medicine and treatment of illness
requiring or relating to treatment by a doctor or medical professional
examples: She's studying at medical school
Medical research has advanced significantly
He needs medical attention immediately
The medical emergency required quick action

definitions: needing much effort, skill, or planning to succeed; hard to do or carry out
hard to please, satisfy, or manage; causing problems or trouble
examples: Learning a new language is difficult but rewarding
The test included several difficult questions
He can be difficult to work with sometimes
She's going through a difficult period in life

definitions: belonging to or concerning one particular person or group; not public
owned by an individual or company rather than the state or public
secluded from the presence, sight, or intrusion of others; offering privacy
examples: She keeps her private life separate from work
This is private property, not public land
He works for a private company
They attend a private school
We found a private spot for our picnic
The meeting was held in a private room

definitions: easily understood or done; presenting no difficulty to comprehend
plain, basic, or uncomplicated in form, design, or style
composed of a single element; not compound or complex in structure
examples: The instructions are simple to follow
It's a simple problem with an easy solution
She wore a simple black dress
They live a simple life in the country
Water is a simple molecule
This is a simple sentence structure

definitions: lacking sufficient money to live at a comfortable standard
of inferior quality, value, or performance; below acceptable standard
deserving pity or sympathy; unfortunate in circumstances or condition
examples: Poor families struggle to afford basic necessities
He grew up poor but worked hard
The restaurant serves poor quality food
Her poor performance led to dismissal
The poor child lost both parents
Poor thing, she's been so sick lately

definitions: occurring, found, or done often; prevalent or widespread in nature
shared by, belonging to, or affecting two or more people or things
ordinary, usual, or familiar; not rare or special in any way
examples: Rain is common in this region
It's a common mistake among beginners
We have common interests in music
The two cultures share common traditions
He's just a common worker, not management
Common sense tells us to be careful

definitions: having a resemblance in appearance, character, or quantity without being identical
of the same kind, nature, or category; related in type or class
examples: The two paintings are similar in style
Their experiences were remarkably similar
All mammals have similar characteristics
These problems require similar solutions

definitions: gone by in time and no longer existing; belonging to former times
beyond in position, further than; on the far side of something
having existed or occurred in an earlier time; former or previous
examples: We can't change past events
The past year has been challenging
Drive past the church and turn right
It's just past the intersection
She met her past employer at the conference
Past experience has taught us caution

definitions: having a high degree of heat or temperature; very warm
containing spices that produce a burning sensation in mouth
currently popular, fashionable, or in demand; very current or topical
examples: The hot weather made everyone uncomfortable
Be careful, the plate is very hot
This curry is too hot for me
She loves hot Mexican food
That's the hot new restaurant downtown
This topic is hot in the news right now

definitions: existing in or formed by nature; not made or caused by humans
normal, expected, or instinctive; in accordance with nature of things
not artificial, manufactured, or processed; genuine and authentic
examples: The park preserves natural habitats
Natural disasters can strike without warning
It's natural to feel nervous before exams
Children have a natural curiosity
She prefers natural fabrics like cotton
The actress has natural blonde hair

definitions: sufficiently great or important to be worthy of attention; noteworthy or meaningful
large enough to be important or have an effect; substantial in amount
examples: This is a significant moment in history
The study revealed significant findings
There was a significant increase in sales
We need significant funding for this project

definitions: constituting the whole of something; complete with nothing missing
not broken, damaged, or decayed; maintained in original wholeness
examples: She read the entire book in one day
The entire family attended the wedding
The vase remained entire despite the earthquake
Keep the document entire for legal purposes

definitions: requiring thought, concentration, or application; important and deserving attention
sincere and in earnest rather than joking or half-hearted
significant in degree, amount, or consequences; giving cause for concern
examples: This is a serious matter requiring discussion
She's serious about her career goals
I'm being serious, not joking
He had a serious expression on his face
The patient is in serious condition
We face serious environmental challenges

definitions: relating to money matters, income, expenditures, or monetary resources
relating to the management of money, banking, investments, or financial systems
examples: They're having financial difficulties
We need financial support for the project
She works as a financial advisor
The financial markets are volatile today

definitions: pleasing the senses or mind aesthetically; having qualities of beauty
excellent, wonderful, or very satisfactory; used to express approval
examples: The sunset was absolutely beautiful
She has a beautiful singing voice
That was a beautiful shot in tennis
What a beautiful idea for the party

definitions: arousing curiosity or interest; catching and holding one's attention
engaging or exciting and holding the attention or curiosity
examples: The documentary presented interesting facts about ocean life
She has an interesting perspective on the issue
The plot becomes more interesting in chapter three
He's an interesting person to talk with

definitions: on or toward the side of the body that is west when facing north
remaining after others have gone or been used; still available
relating to liberal, socialist, or radical political views
examples: Turn left at the traffic light
She writes with her left hand
Only two cookies were left in the jar
Is there any pizza left from yesterday?
The left wing of the party opposes this bill
She has left-leaning political views

definitions: of, from, in, or characteristic of a country other than one's own
strange and unfamiliar; not belonging naturally to a place or situation
examples: She studied foreign languages in college
Foreign investors bought the company
The concept was foreign to their culture
Such behavior is foreign to his nature

definitions: extremely large in size, amount, or physical dimensions
very great in scale, degree, or scope; enormous in extent
examples: Elephants are huge animals
They live in a huge house
The decision had huge implications
She's made huge progress this year

definitions: of or relating to the body as opposed to the mind
relating to things perceived through senses rather than mind; material
involving bodily contact, action, or vigorous activity
examples: Regular physical exercise improves health
The doctor performed a physical examination
We study the physical properties of matter
Physical evidence was found at the scene
Football is a very physical sport
The job requires physical strength

definitions: of, based on, or concerned with the law or legal system
permitted, recognized, or required by law; lawful and legitimate
examples: She sought legal advice from a lawyer
The legal system protects citizens' rights
Is it legal to park here?
They took legal action against the company

definitions: coming at the end of a series, process, or activity; last
allowing no further doubt, debate, or change; decisive and conclusive
examples: This is the final chapter of the book
We reached the final destination
The judge's decision is final
She had the final say in the matter

definitions: having all required elements, qualities, or characteristics; without defects
precisely accurate or exact; exactly fitting the need in situation
complete and absolute in quality or nature; total and unqualified
examples: She has perfect vision
The weather was perfect for our picnic
This is the perfect solution to our problem
You arrived at the perfect time
There was perfect silence in the room
They are in perfect agreement

definitions: protected from or not exposed to danger, risk, or injury
not likely to cause or lead to harm, injury, or damage
cautious and unenterprising; not likely to take risks or chances
examples: The children are safe at home
Keep your valuables in a safe place
This toy is safe for young children
Is this water safe to drink?
He made a safe investment choice
Let's take the safe route home

definitions: generally assumed or believed to be the case without proof
expected or required to do something according to rules or arrangements
intended, designed, or meant to be or do something
examples: The supposed thief was actually innocent
This is supposed to be a secret
You're supposed to arrive by nine
We're not supposed to park here
What's that supposed to mean?
The meeting was supposed to start earlier

definitions: at or forming the center; in the middle of something
of crucial importance; principal, essential, or primary in nature
controlled or organized from a single place or by single authority
examples: The hotel is in a central location
Central Park is in the middle of Manhattan
Trust is central to any relationship
This is the central theme of the book
The company uses a central database
Central heating warms the entire building

definitions: most important, consequential, or influential; chief in size or importance
principal or primary among several; predominant in influence or effect
examples: The main reason for leaving was money
What's the main ingredient in this dish?
The main road leads directly downtown
She plays the main character in the film

definitions: with little or no light; not receiving, reflecting, or radiating light
of a deep or intense color, especially closer to black than white
mysterious, hidden, or not easily understood; characterized by tragedy or unpleasantness
examples: The room was completely dark
It gets dark early in winter
She has dark brown eyes
He prefers dark chocolate
The movie explores dark themes
Those were dark days in our history

definitions: of the color between green and violet in spectrum; color of clear sky
feeling or showing sadness, depression, or melancholy
informal: characterized by coarse or indecent humor; risque or pornographic
examples: The blue ocean stretched to the horizon
She wore a navy blue suit
He's been feeling blue since she left
Don't be blue, things will improve
The comedian told some blue jokes
That's a rather blue movie

definitions: clearly defined, identified, or stated with precision and detail
relating to one particular thing and not others; particular rather than general
unique or peculiar to a particular thing, place, or phenomenon
examples: Please give specific examples
We need specific instructions to proceed
This tool has a specific purpose
I'm looking for a specific book
The disease has specific symptoms
This feature is specific to our model

definitions: relating to or involving the whole world; worldwide in scope or application
considering or including all parts, aspects, or elements; comprehensive
examples: Climate change is a global problem
The company has global operations
We need a global solution to this issue
Take a global view of the situation

definitions: of different kinds, forms, or types; showing variety or diversity
more than one; several but not very many; a number of
examples: The store sells various types of bread
People have various opinions on this topic
Various people have complained about the noise
We tried various methods to solve it
